§ 4.3 Prime & GCD's

Definition: Prime/Composite

  • An Integer p is a Prime if its only divisors are itself and 1

  • A composite is any number that is not a Prime

Theorem 4.3.1

Every integer has a unique prime factorization
n=p1a1⋅p2a2⋯pnann=p_{1}^{a_{1}}\cdot p_{2}^{a_{2}}\cdots p_{n}^{a_{n}}n=p​1​a​1​​​​⋅p​2​a​2​​​​⋯p​n​a​n​​​​

Example 1

What is the prime factorization of the following?
a) 100


100\quad100\quad100
/\/\quad\backslash/\
425\quad4\quad\quad25\quad425
/\/\\quad/\quad\backslash\quad/\quad\backslash\quad/\/\
22552\quad2\quad5\quad52255

b) 3=3⋅13=3\cdot13=3⋅1

c)999


999\quad999\quad999
/\/\quad\backslash/\
9111\quad9\quad\quad111\quad9111
/\/\\quad/\quad\backslash\quad/\quad\backslash\quad/\/\
333373\quad3\quad3\quad3733337

Theorem 4.3.3

If n is a composite number then ∃p≤n\exists p \leq \sqrt{n}∃p≤√​n​​​ such that p is prime and p∣np|np∣n

proof:

Since n is composite ∃a,b∈Z\exists a,b\in\mathbb{Z}∃a,b∈Z such that n=a⋅bn=a\cdot bn=a⋅b
Assume that a>na>\sqrt{n}a>√​n​​​ and b>nb>\sqrt{n}b>√​n​​​
Then, a⋅b>n⋅n=na\cdot b>\sqrt{n}\cdot\sqrt{n}=na⋅b>√​n​​​⋅√​n​​​=n, a contradiction.
Hence a>na>\sqrt{n}a>√​n​​​ and b>nb>\sqrt{n}b>√​n​​​ is false.

i.e. ┐(p⋀q)≡┐p⋁┐q\urcorner (p\bigwedge q)\equiv \urcorner p\bigvee \urcorner q┐(p⋀q)≡┐p⋁┐q
If a is prime and a≤na\leq\sqrt{n}a≤√​n​​​, then we are done because a∣na|na∣n by assumption.
Otherwise, a is composite, by THM 4.3.1
a=p1a1⋅p2a2⋯pkaka=p_{1}^{a_{1}}\cdot p_{2}^{a_{2}}\cdots p_{k}^{a_{k}}a=p​1​a​1​​​​⋅p​2​a​2​​​​⋯p​k​a​k​​​​
And we are hone because pip_{i}p​i​​ for alli∈[l,k]i\in [l,k]i∈[l,k] divide n (This is true because n=a⋅qn=a\cdot qn=a⋅q)
and since is true that pi<a≤ap_{i}<a\leq\sqrt{a}p​i​​<a≤√​a​​​
\quad
Moreover,
\quadif a∣n⇒n=a⋅q,q∈Za|n\Rightarrow n=a\cdot q,q\in\mathbb{Z}a∣n⇒n=a⋅q,q∈Z
=p1a1⋯pi−1ai−1⋯piai⋯pi+1ai+1⋯pkak⋅q\quad\quad\quad\quad\quad=p_{1}^{a_{1}}\cdots p_{i-1}^{a_{i-1}}\cdots p_{i}^{a_{i}}\cdots p_{i+1}^{a_{i+1}}\cdots p_{k}^{a_{k}}\cdot q=p​1​a​1​​​​⋯p​i−1​a​i−1​​​​⋯p​i​a​i​​​​⋯p​i+1​a​i+1​​​​⋯p​k​a​k​​​​⋅q
=pi[p1a1⋯piai−1⋯pkak]⋅q\quad\quad\quad\quad\quad=p_{i}[p_{1}^{a_{1}}\cdots p_{i}^{a_{i-1}}\cdots p_{k}^{a_{k}}]\cdot q=p​i​​[p​1​a​1​​​​⋯p​i​a​i−1​​​​⋯p​k​a​k​​​​]⋅q
=pi⋅Q\quad\quad\quad\quad\quad=p_{i}\cdot Q=p​i​​⋅Q
⇒n=pi⋅Q\quad\quad\quad\Rightarrow n=p_{i}\cdot Q⇒n=p​i​​⋅Q
⇒n=pi∣n\quad\quad\quad\Rightarrow n=p_{i}|n⇒n=p​i​​∣n
Hence


pi≤np_{i}\leq\sqrt{n}p​i​​≤√​n​​​ is a prime that divides n.
If a>na>\sqrt{n}a>√​n​​​ then b≤nb\leq\sqrt{n}b≤√​n​​​ is A MUST.

Example 2

Show 61 is prime
Assume 61 is composite. By THM 4.3.2
∃p≤161\exists{p}\leq\sqrt{161}∃p≤√​161​​​ such that p is prime & divides 61.
p≤61≤64=8p\leq\sqrt{61}\leq\sqrt{64}=8p≤√​61​​​≤√​64​​​=8
Primes in range 1 - 8: 2,3,5,7
2∤612\nmid612∤61
3∤613\nmid613∤61
5∤615\nmid615∤61
7∤617\nmid617∤61
Hence
61 cannot be composite.
i.e. 61 is prime.

Algorithm For Prime Factorization: Trial Division Algorithm.

To find prime factorization of composite n,

  1. Divide n by successive primes beginning p=2p=2p=2.

  2. If n=p⋅kk∈Zn=p\cdot{k}\quad k\in\mathbb{Z}n=p⋅kk∈Z, then
    \quadi) kkk is prime. →\rightarrow→done
    \quadii) kkk is composite. →\rightarrow→repeat

Example 3

Find prime factorization of 7007 using Trial Division.


7007\quad7007\quad7007
/\/\quad\backslash/\
71001\quad7\quad\quad1001\quad71001
/\\quad\quad\quad\quad/\quad\backslash\quad/\
7143\quad\quad\quad7\quad1437143
/\\quad\quad\quad\quad\quad/\quad\backslash/\
1113\quad\quad\quad\quad\quad11\quad131113

Theorem 4.3.3

There are infinitely many Primes

Proof

Assume p1,p2,....,pnp_{1}, p_{2},...., p_{n}p​1​​,p​2​​,....,p​n​​ are all Primes i.e.i.e.i.e. finite number of Primes.
Construct Q=p1⋅p2⋯pn+1∈ZQ = p_{1}\cdot p_{2}\cdots p_{n} + 1 \in\mathbb{Z}Q=p​1​​⋅p​2​​⋯p​n​​+1∈Z

Two possibilities:
i) QQQ is Composite


If Q is Composite then
Q=a⋅ba,b∈ZQ = a\cdot{b}\quad a,b \in \mathbb{Z}Q=a⋅ba,b∈Z
By THM 4.3.1 aaa and bbb have unique Prime factorizations.
a=p1an⋯pnana = p_{1}^{a_{n}}\cdots p_{n}^{a_{n}}a=p​1​a​n​​​​⋯p​n​a​n​​​​
b=p1bn⋯pnbnb = p_{1}^{b_{n}}\cdots p_{n}^{b_{n}}b=p​1​b​n​​​​⋯p​n​b​n​​​​

Hence

Q−p1⋅p2⋯pn=1Q-p_{1}\cdot p_{2}\cdots p_{n} =1Q−p​1​​⋅p​2​​⋯p​n​​=1
a⋅b−p1⋅p2⋯pn=1a\cdot b-p_{1}\cdot p_{2}\cdots p_{n} =1a⋅b−p​1​​⋅p​2​​⋯p​n​​=1
p1a1⋯pnan+bn−p1⋅p2⋅pn=1p_{1}^{a_1}\cdots p_{n}^{a_{n}+b_{n}}-p_{1}\cdot p_{2}\cdot p_{n}=1p​1​a​1​​​​⋯p​n​a​n​​+b​n​​​​−p​1​​⋅p​2​​⋅p​n​​=1
pi[p1a1+b1⋯piai+bi−1⋯pnan+bn−p1⋅p2⋯pi−1⋅pi+1⋅pn]=1p_{i}[p_{1}^{a_{1}+b_{1}} \cdots p_{i}^{a_{i}+b_{i}-1} \cdots p_{n}^{a_{n}+b_{n}}-p_{1}\cdot p_{2}\cdots p_{i-1}\cdot p_{i+1}\cdot p_{n}]=1p​i​​[p​1​a​1​​+b​1​​​​⋯p​i​a​i​​+b​i​​−1​​⋯p​n​a​n​​+b​n​​​​−p​1​​⋅p​2​​⋯p​i−1​​⋅p​i+1​​⋅p​n​​]=1
pi⋅q=1p_{i}\cdot q=1p​i​​⋅q=1
⇒pi∣1\Rightarrow p_{i}|1⇒p​i​​∣1 impossible pi>1p_{i}>1p​i​​>1. (prime)
⇒Q\Rightarrow Q⇒Q is NOT composite.

Then,
ii) QQQ is prime. ⇐a\Leftarrow a⇐a contradiction to existence of n primes.
Hence there are an infinite number of primes.

Cute fact:   
*Largest prime number discovered so far is (2^74207281) -1 in the year of 2016.
GIMPS - (Greate Internet Mersenne Prime Search) *
 
*Primes of the form (2^p)-1 are called Mersenne Primes. *
P - prime

Gcd's & LCM's

Definition GCD


The Greatest Common Divisor of a and b, denoted \quad
gcd(a,b)gcd(a,b)gcd(a,b) is the largest d∈Zd\in\mathbb{Z}d∈Z such that d∣ad|ad∣a and d∣bd|bd∣b

\quad

Example 4

a)a)a) gcd(24,36)=12gcd(24,36)=12gcd(24,36)=12
b)b)b) gcd(17,22)=1gcd(17,22)=1gcd(17,22)=1 ←\leftarrow← relatively prime

\quad
Definition Pairwise-replatively prime
The integers a1,⋯,ana_{1},\cdots,a_{n}a​1​​,⋯,a​n​​ are Pairwise-replatively prime if gcd(ai,aj)=1gcd(a_{i},a{j})=1gcd(a​i​​,aj)=1
where 1≤i<j≤n1\leq i < j \leq n1≤i<j≤n

Example 5

which list is pairwise relatively prime?
a) 10, 17, 21
gcd(10,17)=1gcd(10,17)=1gcd(10,17)=1
gcd(10,21)=1gcd(10,21)=1gcd(10,21)=1
gcd(17,21)=1gcd(17,21)=1gcd(17,21)=1
YES

b) 10, 19, 24
gcd(10,19)=1gcd(10,19)=1gcd(10,19)=1
gcd(10,24)=2gcd(10,24)=2gcd(10,24)=2
⇒\Rightarrow⇒NOT pairwise relatively prime.

Notice: gcd(24,36)=12gcd(24,36)=12gcd(24,36)=12
24=23⋅324=2^{3}\cdot324=2​3​​⋅3
36=22⋅3236=2^{2}\cdot3^{2}36=2​2​​⋅3​2​​
12=22⋅312=2^{2}\cdot312=2​2​​⋅3

In general

a=p1a1⋯pkaka=p_{1}^{a_{1}}\cdots p_{k}^{a_{k}}a=p​1​a​1​​​​⋯p​k​a​k​​​​
b=p1b1⋯pkbkb=p_{1}^{b_{1}}\cdots p_{k}^{b_{k}}b=p​1​b​1​​​​⋯p​k​b​k​​​​
gcd(a,b)=p1min(a1,b1)⋯p2min(a2,b2)⋯pkmin(ak,bk)gcd(a,b)=p_{1}^{min(a_{1},b_{1})}\cdots p_{2}^{min(a_{2},b_{2})}\cdots p_{k}^{min(a_{k},b_{k})}gcd(a,b)=p​1​min(a​1​​,b​1​​)​​⋯p​2​min(a​2​​,b​2​​)​​⋯p​k​min(a​k​​,b​k​​)​​

4.3 Continued

\quad Since the trial Algorithm takes long, finding GCD of a, b is inefficient by means of prime factorization

Euclidean Algorithm
Suppose we wish to find gcd(24,12)gcd(24,12)gcd(24,12)
\quad 36=1⋅24+1236 = 1\cdot24+1236=1⋅24+12
\quad 24=2⋅12+024 =2\cdot12+024=2⋅12+0
\quad => The last nonzero remainder = GCD

Theorem 4.3.4

\quad Let a=b⋅q+ra=b\cdot q + ra=b⋅q+r a,b,q,r∈Z\qquad a,b,q,r \in \mathbb{Z}a,b,q,r∈Z
\quad\quad then gcd(a,b)gcd(a, b)gcd(a,b) = gdc(b,r)gdc(b,r)gdc(b,r)
\quad proof: goal  d∣a\space d|a d∣a ^  d∣b↔d∣b \space d|b \leftrightarrow d|b ^\space d∣b↔d∣b​ ​​ ^  d∣r\space d|r d∣r
\quad\quad for any divisor d∈Zd\in \mathbb{Z}d∈Z

\quad i.) Assume d∣ad|ad∣a ^ d∣bd|bd∣b
\qquad a=k⋅bk∈Za=k\cdot b \quad k\in \mathbb{Z}a=k⋅bk∈Z
\qquad b=u⋅du∈Zb=u\cdot d \quad u\in \mathbb{Z}b=u⋅du∈Z
a=b⋅q+r\qquad a = b\cdot q+ra=b⋅q+r
r=a−b⋅q\qquad r = a - b\cdot qr=a−b⋅q
   =k⋅d−u⋅d⋅q\qquad\space\space\space = k\cdot d - u\cdot d\cdot q   =k⋅d−u⋅d⋅q
r=d(k−u⋅q)\qquad r = d(k-u\cdot q)r=d(k−u⋅q)
r=d⋅v\qquad r = d\cdot vr=d⋅v
   =d∣r\qquad\space\space\space = d|r   =d∣r

\quad Now assume d∣b d|b\spaced∣b  ^  d∣r\space d|r d∣r
b=d⋅kk∈Z\qquad b=d\cdot k \quad k\in \mathbb{Z}b=d⋅kk∈Z
r=d⋅uu∈Z\qquad r=d\cdot u \quad u\in \mathbb{Z}r=d⋅uu∈Z
a=b⋅q+r\qquad\quad a = b\cdot q +ra=b⋅q+r
   =d⋅k⋅q+d⋅u\qquad\quad\space\space\space =d\cdot k\cdot q + d\cdot u   =d⋅k⋅q+d⋅u
   =a=d⋅v\qquad\quad\space\space\space = a = d\cdot v   =a=d⋅v
   =d∣a\qquad\quad\space\space\space = d|a   =d∣a

\quad Since the results hold for any divisor ddd, they are true in particular for the greatest common divisor
i.e.gcd(a,b)=gcd(b,r)\qquad i.e.\quad gcd(a,b) = gcd(b,r)i.e.gcd(a,b)=gcd(b,r)

Example 7

\quad Find the gcd of...
\quad a.) gcd(120,500)gcd(120,500)gcd(120,500)
500=4⋅120+20\qquad 500 = 4\cdot 120 + 20500=4⋅120+20
120=6⋅20+0\qquad 120 = 6\cdot 20 + 0120=6⋅20+0
=>gcd(120,500)=20\qquad => gcd(120,500) = 20=>gcd(120,500)=20

\quad a.) gcd(414,662)gcd(414,662)gcd(414,662)
662=1⋅414+248\qquad 662=1\cdot 414 + 248662=1⋅414+248
248=1⋅248+166\qquad 248=1\cdot248+166248=1⋅248+166
166=2⋅82+2\qquad 166 = 2\cdot 82 + 2166=2⋅82+2
82=41⋅2+0\qquad 82 = 41\cdot2 +082=41⋅2+0

Algorithm: GCD

gcd(x,y)\quad gcd(x,y)gcd(x,y)
a=max(x,y)\qquad a = max(x,y)a=max(x,y)
b=min(x,y)\qquad b = min(x,y)b=min(x,y)
r=a mod b\qquad r = a\space mod\space br=a mod b
while r != 0\qquad while\space r\space !=\space 0while r != 0
a=b\qquad\quad a=ba=b
b=r\qquad\quad b=rb=r
r=a mod b\qquad\quad r=a\space mod\space br=a mod b
return b\qquad return\space breturn b

Theorem 4.3.5

\quad Let a,b∈Za,b\in \mathbb{Z}a,b∈Z then ∃s,t∈Z\exists s,t\in \mathbb{Z}∃s,t∈Z such that
s⋅a+t⋅b=gcd(a,b)\qquad\quad s\cdot a + t\cdot b = gcd(a,b)s⋅a+t⋅b=gcd(a,b)
=>Bezout′sIdentity<=\quad => Bezout's Identity <==>Bezout​′​​sIdentity<=

Example 8

FindBezout′sIdentity\quad Find Bezout's IdentityFindBezout​′​​sIdentity

a.)gcd(414,662)\qquad a.) gcd(414,662)a.)gcd(414,662)

414=1⋅248+166\qquad\quad 414 = 1\cdot 248 + 166414=1⋅248+166

166=2⋅82+2\qquad\quad 166 = 2\cdot 82 + 2166=2⋅82+2

=>248=662−414\quad => 248 = 662 - 414=>248=662−414
=>166=414−248\quad => 166 = 414 - 248=>166=414−248
=>82=248−166\quad => 82 = 248 - 166=>82=248−166
=>2=166−2⋅(82)\quad => 2 = 166 - 2\cdot (82)=>2=166−2⋅(82)

=>2=8⋅414−5⋅662\quad => 2 = 8\cdot 414 - 5\cdot 662=>2=8⋅414−5⋅662

4.4 Solving Congruences

\quad Linear Congruences
\quad goal: Solve
\qquad a⋅x≡b (mod m)a\cdot x \equiv b\space (mod\space m)a⋅x≡b (mod m)
\quad for xxx
\quad in algebra: a⋅x=ba\cdot x = ba⋅x=b
\qquad\qquad\qquad x=bax=\frac{b}{a}x=​a​​b​​

\quad Q: x≡ba(mod m)x \equiv \frac{b}{a}(mod\space m)x≡​a​​b​​(mod m)
\quad A: Consider
14≡8 mod 6\qquad 14 \equiv 8\space mod\space 614≡8 mod 6
\quad Is it true that 7≡4 (mod 3)7\equiv 4\space(mod\space 3)7≡4 (mod 3)?
7−4=3→6∤3\qquad\qquad\qquad 7-4 = 3 \rightarrow 6 \nmid 37−4=3→6∤3

\quad Short Answer: No
a⋅x≡b(mod m)\qquad\qquad a\cdot x \equiv b(mod\space m)a⋅x≡b(mod m)
\qquad does not mean
x≡ba(mod m)\qquad\qquad x\equiv \frac{b}{a}(mod\space m)x≡​a​​b​​(mod m)
\qquad(Always)

\quad Q: Are there any special circumstances under which
x≡ba(mod m)\qquad x \equiv \frac{b}{a}(mod\space m)x≡​a​​b​​(mod m)
\quad given that
\qquad\qquad a⋅x≡b(mod m)?a\cdot x \equiv b(mod\space m)?a⋅x≡b(mod m)?
\quad A: Short Answer: Yes.
\quad Long Answer:
\qquad Need two results:
\qquad i.) Lemma: gcd(a,b)=1gcd(a,b) = 1gcd(a,b)=1 ^ a∣bc →a∣ca|bc\space \rightarrow a|ca∣bc →a∣c
a,b,c∈Z\qquad\qquad a,b,c\in\mathbb{Z}a,b,c∈Z
\qquad Proof:
∙ gcd(a,b)=1\qquad\qquad\bullet\space gcd(a,b)=1∙ gcd(a,b)=1 then ∃s,t∈Z\quad\exists s,t\in\mathbb{Z}∃s,t∈Z
\qquad\qquad\quad s⋅a+t⋅b=1s\cdot a + t\cdot b = 1s⋅a+t⋅b=1
∙ a∣b⋅c\qquad\qquad\bullet\space a|b\cdot c∙ a∣b⋅c then b⋅c=a⋅kk∈Zb\cdot c=a\cdot k\qquad k\in\mathbb{Z}b⋅c=a⋅kk∈Z
\qquad\qquad\quad s⋅a+b⋅t=1s\cdot a + b\cdot t = 1s⋅a+b⋅t=1
\qquad\qquad\quad s⋅a⋅c+b⋅t⋅c⋅=cs\cdot a\cdot c + b\cdot t\cdot c\cdot = cs⋅a⋅c+b⋅t⋅c⋅=c
\qquad\qquad\quad s⋅a⋅c+t⋅a⋅k⋅=cs\cdot a\cdot c + t\cdot a\cdot k\cdot = cs⋅a⋅c+t⋅a⋅k⋅=c
\qquad\qquad\quad a⋅(s⋅c+t⋅k)=ca\cdot(s\cdot c+ t\cdot k)=ca⋅(s⋅c+t⋅k)=c
\qquad\qquad\quad =>a∣c=> a|c=>a∣c

\qquad i.) 4.3.6
\qquad\qquad Let m∈Za,b,c∈Zm\in\mathbb{Z}\qquad a,b,c\in\mathbb{Z}m∈Za,b,c∈Z
\qquad\qquad\quad a⋅c≡b⋅c (mod m)a\cdot c \equiv b\cdot c\space (mod\space m)a⋅c≡b⋅c (mod m) ^ gcd(c,m)=1gcd(c,m) = 1gcd(c,m)=1
\qquad\qquad Proof →\rightarrow→ ∙ a≡b (mod m)\bullet\space a\equiv b\space (mod\space m)∙ a≡b (mod m)
\qquad\qquad\qquad\qquad a⋅c−b⋅c=m⋅kk∈Za\cdot c - b\cdot c = m\cdot k\qquad k\in\mathbb{Z}a⋅c−b⋅c=m⋅kk∈Z
∙ gcd(c,m)=1\qquad\qquad\qquad\qquad\bullet\space gcd(c,m) = 1∙ gcd(c,m)=1
 s⋅c+t⋅m=1\qquad\qquad\qquad\qquad\space s\cdot c + t\cdot m = 1 s⋅c+t⋅m=1
 a⋅c−b⋅c=m⋅k\qquad\qquad\qquad\qquad\space a\cdot c - b\cdot c = m\cdot k a⋅c−b⋅c=m⋅k
 c (a−b)=m⋅k(∗)\qquad\qquad\qquad\qquad\space c\space (a-b)=m\cdot k\qquad ( * ) c (a−b)=m⋅k(∗)
 c∣m⋅k\qquad\qquad\qquad\qquad\space c|m\cdot k c∣m⋅k
 c∣k\qquad\qquad\qquad\qquad\space c|k c∣k

\qquad\qquad\qquad in (∗)( * )(∗)

 a≡b (mod m)\qquad\qquad\qquad\qquad\space a\equiv b\space (mod\space m) a≡b (mod m)

∙\qquad\qquad\qquad\quad\qquad\bullet∙ a≡b (mod m)a\equiv b\space(mod\space m)a≡b (mod m)

Theorem 4.4.1

\quad Let a,m∈Zm>1a,m\in\mathbb{Z}\qquad m>1a,m∈Zm>1
\quad gcd(a,m)=1gcd(a,m)=1gcd(a,m)=1 then ∃a¯∈Z\exists \bar{a}\in\mathbb{Z}∃​a​¯​​∈Z
\quad such that
\qquad a¯⋅a≡1 (mod m)\bar{a}\cdot a\equiv 1\space(mod\space m)​a​¯​​⋅a≡1 (mod m)

\quad If gcd(a,m)=1gcd(a,m)=1gcd(a,m)=1 and m>1m>1m>1
 \quad\space  then ∃a¯∈Z \exists \bar{a}\in\mathbb{Z}\space∃​a​¯​​∈Z  such that
\quad\quad a¯⋅a≡1 (mod m)\bar{a}\cdot a \equiv 1\space(mod\space m)​a​¯​​⋅a≡1 (mod m)
 \quad\space  and a¯\bar{a}​a​¯​​ is unique modulo mmm

\quad Proof (a,m)=1(a,m)=1(a,m)=1
\qquad ∃s,t∈Zs⋅a+t⋅m=1\exists s,t \in\mathbb{Z} \qquad s\cdot a + t\cdot m = 1∃s,t∈Zs⋅a+t⋅m=1
\quad Notice, (s⋅a+t⋅m)−1=0⋅m(s\cdot a + t\cdot m) - 1 =0\cdot m(s⋅a+t⋅m)−1=0⋅m
\quad Hence s⋅a+t⋅m≡1 (mod m)s\cdot a + t\cdot m\equiv 1\space(mod\space m)s⋅a+t⋅m≡1 (mod m)
\quad Also notice
\qquad t⋅m=0 (mod m)t\cdot m = 0\space(mod\space m)t⋅m=0 (mod m)
\quad Hence,
\qquad s⋅a+t⋅m≡s⋅a+0 (mod m)s\cdot a + t\cdot m \equiv s\cdot a + 0\space(mod\space m)s⋅a+t⋅m≡s⋅a+0 (mod m)
\quad By Lemma 2
s⋅a≡1 (mod m)\qquad s\cdot a\equiv 1\space(mod\space m)s⋅a≡1 (mod m)
\quad i.e. a¯=s\bar{a}= s\qquad​a​¯​​=s Bezout Coeff. of aaa

\qquad assume that
\qquad\quad s⋅a≡1 (mod m)s\cdot a \equiv 1\space(mod\space m)s⋅a≡1 (mod m)
\qquad and z⋅a≡1 (mod m)z\cdot a \equiv 1\space(mod\space m)z⋅a≡1 (mod m)

\quad what are the solutions to

x≡−8 (mod 7)\qquad\quad x\equiv-8\space(mod\space 7)x≡−8 (mod 7)
x+8=7⋅k\qquad\quad x+8=7\cdot kx+8=7⋅k
x=7⋅k−8k∈Z\qquad\quad x = 7\cdot k-8\qquad k\in\mathbb{Z}x=7⋅k−8k∈Z
x=7⋅k−7−1\qquad\quad x = 7\cdot k-7-1x=7⋅k−7−1
x=7 (k−1)−1\qquad\quad x = 7\space(k-1)-1x=7 (k−1)−1
